newsitem.title: FRANCE: Gaumont shares hit high on "Fifth Element" viewing.
newsitem.headline: Gaumont shares hit high on "Fifth Element" viewing.

text.p: Shares in French film company Gaumont set a 1997 high on Tuesday after being boosted on Monday by strong viewing figures for Luc Besson's new film, "The Fifth Element", sector specialists said.
The stock opened at 490 francs on Tuesday, a new year high, after rising over five percent on Monday.

"Last night the film had 367,885 entries in Paris and its suburbs, which allows us to envisage a first week flirting with two million entries in France," said an official at magazine Le Film Francais, which counts filmgoers in France.
"One film and the Gaumont share, generally left on one side, is again in the limelight," said one analyst.
"It is too soon to re-calculate the precise figures, but it is clear that its (Gaumont's) 1997 results will be strongly up on 1996," the analyst added.
In 1996 Gaumont had net attributable profit of 56.1 million francs.
"The Fifth Element's" budget is around 500 million francs. Gaumont has planned to spend 950 million francs on new productions this year and 600 million next year.
Analysts said "The Fifth Element's" budget is already offset by pre-purchases of the film abroad.
No one was available for comment at Gaumont.
